questions.question_text: What does 'existence' refer to in metaphysics?

options.A: The logical structure of valid arguments as studied in formal deductive reasoning systems.
options.B: The process by which physical matter transforms into energy according to thermodynamic laws.
options.C: The state of having being or reality, as opposed to nonexistence and nonbeing.
options.D: The subjective experience of consciousness that arises from complex neural network activity.

questions.question_text: In philosophy, what does 'reality' broadly refer to?

options.A: The set of empirically verified scientific theories that have achieved consensus among researchers.
options.B: The range of logically possible propositions that can be expressed in a formal symbolic language.
options.C: The collection of sensory impressions that an individual organism receives during its conscious lifetime.
options.D: The totality of all things that exist, encompassing both observable and non-observable entities.

questions.question_text: In the philosophy of time, what does the A-theory (associated with presentism) claim about temporal existence?

options.A: Temporal passage is reducible to the spatial ordering of events along a dimension.
options.B: Only the present moment is real, and time genuinely passes or flows.
options.C: Time is merely an illusion generated by human cognitive limitations and biases.
options.D: Past, present, and future all exist equally within an unchanging block universe.

questions.question_text: What is the substantivalist view of space in philosophy?

options.A: Space is a mental framework imposed by the mind to organize sensory experiences.
options.B: Space is an independently existing entity that persists even without any material objects.
options.C: Space is nothing more than a set of distance and direction relations among objects.
options.D: Space is an emergent property arising from quantum gravitational interactions between particles.

questions.question_text: According to David Hume, how do humans come to understand causation?

options.A: Through mathematical deduction from self-evident axioms about the logical relations among physical objects.
options.B: Through habit and custom, by repeatedly observing one type of event regularly following another.
options.C: Through innate rational intuition that directly grasps necessary connections between cause and effect.
options.D: Through divine revelation that discloses the hidden causal structure underlying all natural phenomena.

questions.question_text: What is the central question addressed by the philosophy of mind?

options.A: The computational algorithms required to simulate human reasoning in artificial intelligence systems.
options.B: The nature of mental phenomena and the relationship between mind and body.
options.C: The neurochemical mechanisms that produce specific behaviors in mammalian brain structures.
options.D: The developmental stages of human intelligence from infancy through late adulthood.

questions.question_text: In metaphysics, what principle states that x and y are identical if and only if they share all the same properties?

options.A: The Principle of Sufficient Reason, requiring every fact to have an explanation.
options.B: Ockham's Razor, which mandates selecting the simplest competing hypothesis available.
options.C: Leibniz's Law, also known as the identity of indiscernibles.
options.D: Hume's Fork, distinguishing relations of ideas from empirical matters of fact.

questions.question_text: Which ancient Greek philosopher argued that change is the fundamental principle of reality, famously claiming one cannot step into the same river twice?

options.A: Democritus, who proposed that indivisible atoms moving through empty void constitute reality.
options.B: Heraclitus, who held that everything is in constant flux and perpetual change.
options.C: Pythagoras, who maintained that numerical ratios and mathematical harmony underlie all existence.
options.D: Parmenides, who argued that only unchanging being is real and change is illusion.

questions.question_text: What position in philosophy holds that free will and determinism are compatible with each other?

options.A: Compatibilism, the view accepted by a majority of contemporary philosophers.
options.B: Libertarianism, which asserts that genuinely free actions require causal indeterminism.
options.C: Hard determinism, which denies free will because all events are causally necessitated.
options.D: Fatalism, which claims that all events are predetermined regardless of human choices.

questions.question_text: According to Plato, what are the three parts of the human soul?

options.A: Sensation (aisthesis), emotion (pathos), and volition (boulesis) as experiential capacities.
options.B: Intellect (nous), will (thelesis), and desire (orexis) as independent rational substances.
options.C: Reason (logistikon), spirit (thymoeides), and appetite (epithymetikon).
options.D: Memory (mnemonikon), perception (aisthesis), and imagination (phantasia) as cognitive faculties.

questions.question_text: Which philosopher formulated the ontological argument for God's existence in 1078, defining God as 'a being than which no greater can be conceived'?

options.A: René Descartes, in his work Meditations on First Philosophy
options.B: Thomas Aquinas, in his work Summa Theologica
options.C: Anselm of Canterbury, in his work Proslogion
options.D: Augustine of Hippo, in his work City of God

questions.question_text: In classical physics and chemistry, what two fundamental characteristics define matter?

options.A: Exhibiting wave-particle duality and quantum spin angular momentum
options.B: Possessing electrical charge and producing magnetic field interactions
options.C: Emitting radiation and generating gravitational wave distortions
options.D: Having mass and occupying space by having volume

questions.question_text: In the philosophy of mathematics, what position holds that numbers exist as mind-independent abstract entities in a realm separate from the physical world?

options.A: Nominalism, which asserts numbers are convenient labels for patterns among concrete particulars
options.B: Formalism, which asserts numbers are syntactic symbols manipulated by explicit formal rules
options.C: Intuitionism, which asserts numbers are mental constructions produced by finite cognitive processes
options.D: Platonism, which asserts numbers are real abstract objects existing independently of human thought

questions.question_text: What does ontology, as a branch of metaphysics, primarily investigate?

options.A: The origins of moral value, ethical obligation, and normative behavioral standards
options.B: The principles of valid deductive inference and formal logical system construction
options.C: The nature of being, what kinds of entities exist, and their fundamental categories
options.D: The limits of human knowledge, justified belief, and rational epistemic standards

questions.question_text: What is the concept of Laplace's demon meant to illustrate about determinism?

options.A: That an intellect knowing all positions and velocities of every particle could perfectly predict the entire future
options.B: That an observer measuring any quantum state inevitably disturbs it and introduces fundamental uncertainty
options.C: That a being outside of time could freely choose to intervene in any causal sequence at will
options.D: That a sufficiently powerful computer simulating the universe would require infinite energy to operate

questions.question_text: In Aristotle's metaphysics, what is a 'primary substance'?

options.A: A universal form, such as the species horse, that exists independently and can be predicated of many individual things
options.B: A fundamental physical element, such as earth or water, that exists independently and composes all material bodies
options.C: An abstract mathematical object, such as a geometric shape, that exists independently and structures the physical world
options.D: An individual concrete entity, such as a particular horse, that exists independently and cannot be predicated of anything else

questions.question_text: What are the three main philosophical positions regarding the ontological status of properties?

options.A: Idealism, materialism, and phenomenalism
options.B: Realism, nominalism, and conceptualism
options.C: Monism, dualism, and pluralism
options.D: Empiricism, rationalism, and pragmatism

questions.question_text: What distinguishes David Lewis's modal realism from other philosophical accounts of possible worlds?

options.A: Lewis held that all possible worlds are mental, subjective representations existing only within conscious human minds
options.B: Lewis held that all possible worlds are concrete, spatiotemporally real entities of the same kind as our actual world
options.C: Lewis held that all possible worlds are linguistic, fictional descriptions existing only within coherent narrative frameworks
options.D: Lewis held that all possible worlds are abstract, mathematical constructions existing only within formal logical systems

questions.question_text: Which philosopher introduced the concept of possible worlds to argue that God actualized 'the best of all possible worlds'?

options.A: René Descartes, in his 1641 work Meditations on First Philosophy
options.B: Immanuel Kant, in his 1781 work Critique of Pure Reason
options.C: Baruch Spinoza, in his 1677 work Ethics Demonstrated in Geometric Order
options.D: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, in his 1710 work Theodicy

questions.question_text: In Cartesian substance dualism, what are the two fundamentally distinct kinds of substance, and what is each defined by?

options.A: Mind, defined by thinking (res cogitans), and body, defined by spatial extension (res extensa)
options.B: Form, defined by rational structure (res formalis), and matter, defined by sensory quality (res sensibilis)
options.C: Soul, defined by divine origin (res divina), and flesh, defined by biological function (res corporalis)
options.D: Spirit, defined by moral agency (res moralis), and nature, defined by causal necessity (res naturalis)

questions.question_text: In philosophy, physicalism is the thesis that everything that exists is what?

options.A: Physical, or entirely dependent on and determined by physical entities and properties
options.B: Linguistic, constituted by the symbolic structures of language that shape perceived reality
options.C: Mental, originating from consciousness and irreducible to any material substrate whatsoever
options.D: Logical, consisting of abstract formal relations that ground all observable natural phenomena

questions.question_text: What distinguishes abstract objects from concrete objects in metaphysics?

options.A: Abstract objects lack spatiotemporal location and causal powers, unlike concrete objects
options.B: Abstract objects are created by physical processes while concrete objects arise from thought
options.C: Abstract objects exist only in the future whereas concrete objects exist in the present
options.D: Abstract objects are perceptible through the senses while concrete objects require inference

questions.question_text: In Aristotelian metaphysics, what does the essence of a thing refer to?

options.A: The sensory impressions a thing produces in the minds of its various observers
options.B: The set of necessary properties that make a thing what it fundamentally is
options.C: The material substrate from which a thing is physically composed at any moment
options.D: The accidental qualities a thing acquires through interaction with its environment

questions.question_text: In modal logic, what makes a proposition contingent rather than necessary?

options.A: It is false in every possible world and its negation holds as a matter of logical law
options.B: It is neither true nor false in any possible world because it lacks determinate meaning
options.C: It is true in some possible worlds but false in others, depending on how things happen to be
options.D: It is true in every possible world and could not have been false under any circumstances

questions.question_text: What does supervenience mean in philosophy of mind?

options.A: Physical properties are entirely caused by and reducible to prior mental states and intentions
options.B: Mental and physical properties vary completely independently with no systematic correlation at all
options.C: Mental properties cannot differ without a corresponding difference in underlying physical properties
options.D: Higher-level mental properties replace and eliminate the lower-level physical properties they describe

questions.question_text: What is the core claim of nominalism in metaphysics?

options.A: Both universals and particulars exist equally as fundamental constituents of mind-independent reality
options.B: Only particular concrete things exist; universals and abstract objects are merely names or labels
options.C: Abstract mathematical objects are the only true existents and physical particulars are derivative
options.D: Universal forms exist independently of particular things in a separate realm of abstract being

questions.question_text: The problem of universals asks whether properties shared by multiple objects, such as redness, exist independently of those objects. What are the two main realist answers?

options.A: Constructive realism, where universals are social agreements, and eliminative realism, where universals are reducible to physics
options.B: Empirical realism, where universals are discovered by observation, and rational realism, where universals are deduced a priori
options.C: Cartesian realism, where universals exist in the mind, and Kantian realism, where universals structure possible experience
options.D: Platonic realism, where universals exist independently of particulars, and Aristotelian realism, where universals exist only within particulars

questions.question_text: According to the psychological continuity theory of personal identity, what makes a person at one time the same person at a later time?

options.A: Unbroken physical continuity of the same biological organism from birth through natural death
options.B: Overlapping chains of psychological connections such as memories, beliefs, and personality traits
options.C: Ongoing social recognition by others who consistently identify and treat the individual as the same person
options.D: Continuous possession of an immaterial soul that remains numerically identical through all bodily changes

questions.question_text: Compatibilism holds that free will and determinism are mutually compatible. How do compatibilists typically define a free action?

options.A: An action chosen from among genuinely open alternative possibilities that are not fixed by prior causal history
options.B: An action that is completely uncaused, arising from a spontaneous quantum event in the agent's neural processes
options.C: An action whose outcome the agent could not have predicted because of inherent randomness in the causal chain
options.D: An action performed according to the agent's own desires and motivations without external coercion or constraint

questions.question_text: What is mereology the formal study of in philosophy?

options.A: Part-whole relations and how parts compose or constitute larger wholes
options.B: Cause-effect relations and how prior events necessitate subsequent outcomes
options.C: Set-membership relations and how individual elements belong to abstract classes
options.D: Mind-body relations and how mental states interact with physical processes

questions.question_text: Eternalism in the philosophy of time is often called the 'block universe' view. What does it assert about past, present, and future entities?

options.A: Only the present exists, and past and future entities have no ontological standing whatsoever.
options.B: Time is entirely illusory and no temporal entities of any kind genuinely exist.
options.C: All past, present, and future entities are equally real; none is ontologically privileged over the others.
options.D: Past and present entities exist but the future is open and ontologically indeterminate.

questions.question_text: Presentism is the thesis that only present entities exist. How does it treat claims about past or future objects?

options.A: Past entities have existed and future entities will exist, but neither exist now and so have no current ontological status.
options.B: Past and future entities exist as concrete possible worlds distinct from the actual present world.
options.C: Past entities remain fully real in a growing block while future entities are genuinely nonexistent.
options.D: Past and future entities exist in diminished form as abstract objects located outside of spacetime.

questions.question_text: According to bundle theory, what constitutes an ordinary object such as an apple?

options.A: A bundle of co-present properties with no underlying substance or bare particular binding them together.
options.B: A bare particular that possesses no intrinsic properties but serves as a substrate for attributes.
options.C: A single universal instantiated at a unique spatiotemporal location defined by physical laws.
options.D: An arrangement of mereological simples whose collective behavior gives rise to emergent qualities.

questions.question_text: The principle of causal closure of the physical states that every physical effect has a sufficient physical cause. Why does this pose a problem for substance dualism?

options.A: It shows that mental causation violates conservation of energy, so the mind must be a form of dark energy.
options.B: If every physical event already has a sufficient physical cause, non-physical mental substances cannot have causal power over the physical world.
options.C: It entails that free will is impossible under any metaphysical framework, rendering both dualist and physicalist accounts of agency equally untenable.
options.D: It implies that mental events are identical to physical events, eliminating the need for any separate mental substance.

questions.question_text: In philosophy, what distinguishes strong emergence from weak emergence?

options.A: Strongly emergent properties appear gradually over very long time scales while weakly emergent properties arise suddenly and instantaneously from their components.
options.B: Strongly emergent properties are fundamentally irreducible to lower-level components, whereas weakly emergent properties are unexpected but in principle deducible from them.
options.C: Strong emergence occurs only in complex biological systems while weak emergence is restricted to simple physical and chemical systems alone.
options.D: Strong emergence requires the presence of conscious observers in order to manifest while weak emergence occurs entirely independently of any observation.

questions.question_text: In philosophy, natural kinds are categories that 'carve nature at its joints.' Which of the following best characterizes natural kinds?

options.A: Mathematical sets whose membership is determined entirely by formal axiomatic definitions and proofs.
options.B: Groupings that reflect the actual structure of the world rather than depending on human interests or conventions.
options.C: Arbitrary classifications that scientists impose on nature for purely pragmatic laboratory convenience.
options.D: Categories found only in biology that correspond to species defined by reproductive isolation criteria.

questions.question_text: What is the central disagreement between Humean regularity theorists and necessitarians about laws of nature?

options.A: Humeans claim laws are a priori knowable truths while necessitarians claim they can only be discovered through empirical observation.
options.B: Humeans hold that laws merely describe observed regularities, while necessitarians hold that laws express genuine physical necessities that govern events.
options.C: Humeans assert that laws apply only locally while necessitarians assert that laws hold exclusively at cosmological scales.
options.D: Humeans believe laws originate from divine decree while necessitarians believe they emerge from collective scientific agreement.

questions.question_text: Trope theory holds that properties are particular instances rather than universals. How does it explain the similarity between two red objects?

options.A: Each object has its own distinct red trope, and the two tropes resemble each other without being identical or sharing a universal.
options.B: The similarity is merely a psychological projection by human observers and has no real basis in the objects' own intrinsic natures.
options.C: Both objects participate in a single shared universal called 'redness' that exists independently of them in an abstract Platonic realm of forms.
options.D: Both objects instantiate the very same structural property that is defined by their having identical sets of underlying microphysical particle arrangements.

questions.question_text: Metaphysical grounding is a relation in which one fact holds 'in virtue of' another. How does grounding differ from causation?

options.A: Grounding is a special type of efficient causation that operates only between abstract objects rather than concrete events.
options.B: Grounding is a non-causal constitutive dependence relation that explains metaphysical priority, not a temporal process linking earlier events to later effects.
options.C: Grounding is a probabilistic relation that raises the likelihood of the grounded fact whereas causation is strictly deterministic.
options.D: Grounding applies exclusively to necessary logical truths while causation applies exclusively to contingent empirical facts about the natural world.

questions.question_text: Truthmaker theory holds that truth depends on being. According to truthmaker maximalism, what must exist for every true proposition?

options.A: A possible world in which the proposition holds true, regardless of whether any actual concrete entity in reality makes it true.
options.B: A corresponding sentence expressed in an ideal formal language that perfectly mirrors the underlying logical structure of reality itself.
options.C: A coherent set of justified beliefs held by a rational epistemic community that collectively supports and warrants the proposition.
options.D: An entity in the world — a truthmaker — whose existence necessitates the truth of that proposition, with no truthmaker gaps allowed.

questions.question_text: Four-dimensionalism claims that persisting objects extend through time just as they extend through space. According to this view, how do objects persist, and what metaphor describes their temporal extent?

options.A: Objects persist by maintaining an unchanging essential core while shedding accidental properties, forming 'temporal crystals' fixed across spacetime.
options.B: Objects persist by being wholly present at every moment of existence, forming 'spatial snapshots' recurring at each three-dimensional instant.
options.C: Objects persist by continuously recreating themselves at each moment through divine sustenance, forming 'causal chains' linking successive entities.
options.D: Objects persist by having distinct temporal parts at different times, forming 'spacetime worms' extending across four-dimensional spacetime.

questions.question_text: Endurantism offers a rival account of persistence to four-dimensionalism. What is its central claim, and what classical problem does it face regarding change?

options.A: Objects are bundles of temporal parts unified by resemblance relations. It faces the problem of vagueness: how to determine exact boundaries of temporal careers.
options.B: Objects consist of successive momentary stages linked by causation. It faces the problem of material constitution: how colocated objects share identical physical properties.
options.C: Objects are wholly present at each moment without temporal parts. It faces the problem of temporary intrinsics: how one thing has incompatible properties across time.
options.D: Objects exist timelessly outside the causal order without genuine change. It faces the problem of interaction: how timeless entities participate in causal processes.

questions.question_text: Haecceitism concerns whether possible worlds can differ non-qualitatively. What medieval philosopher's concept inspired the term, and what does haecceitism claim?

options.A: From Boethius's personalitas ('personhood'). Haecceitism holds that transworld identity requires sharing all intrinsic qualitative properties with no non-qualitative differences.
options.B: From Thomas Aquinas's quidditas ('whatness'). Haecceitism holds that every individual has a unique essential property determining all qualitative characteristics across worlds.
options.C: From William of Ockham's singularitas ('singularity'). Haecceitism holds that individuals reduce to bundles of universals with no primitive individuality beyond qualities.
options.D: From Duns Scotus's haecceitas ('thisness'). Haecceitism holds that worlds can differ over which individuals occupy which roles without any qualitative difference.

questions.question_text: Ontic structural realism reconceives fundamental reality in philosophy of physics. Who distinguished epistemic from ontic forms, and what does the ontic version claim?

options.A: Bas van Fraassen drew the distinction in 1980. Ontic structural realism claims objects are fundamental and structures are useful mathematical descriptions.
options.B: Howard Stein drew the distinction in 1989. Ontic structural realism claims only observable structures are real while theoretical posits remain instrumental.
options.C: John Worrall drew the distinction in 2003. Ontic structural realism claims objects and structures are equally fundamental co-dependent ontological categories.
options.D: James Ladyman drew the distinction in 1998. Ontic structural realism claims structure is all there is: relations are fundamental, objects derivative.

questions.question_text: David Lewis defended Humean supervenience throughout his career. What does this doctrine claim is the fundamental basis of all worldly facts?

options.A: All facts supervene on a 'grand mechanism' of necessary causal connections linking every event to prior conditions plus nomic necessitation.
options.B: All facts supervene on a 'vast mosaic' of local intrinsic qualities at spacetime points plus spatiotemporal relations -- nothing more.
options.C: All facts supervene on a 'universal field' of mind-independent Platonic universals existing outside spacetime plus instantiation relations to particulars.
options.D: All facts supervene on a 'cosmic web' of dispositional powers possessed by fundamental particles plus irreducible governing natural laws.

questions.question_text: Dialetheism is a heterodox position in philosophy of logic and metaphysics. Who coined the term, what does the view assert, and how does it differ from trivialism?

options.A: Saul Kripke and Hilary Putnam coined it. No contradictions are expressible in formal logic, and unlike trivialism, truth is restricted to analytic necessities.
options.B: Alfred Tarski and Kurt Gödel coined it. Contradictions indicate formal system limits, and unlike trivialism, self-referential sentences lack truth-values entirely.
options.C: Graham Priest and Richard Routley coined it. Some contradictions are true (dialetheia), but unlike trivialism, not all statements are true.
options.D: W.V.O. Quine and Donald Davidson coined it. Contradictions arise only from semantic ambiguity, and unlike trivialism, all contradictions are ultimately resolvable.

questions.question_text: Mereological nihilism takes a radically sparse view of what material objects exist. What does it claim about composite objects, and how does it account for everyday experience?

options.A: No material objects of any kind exist; only immaterial mental states are real. Apparent objects are 'projections of consciousness' causing shared experiences.
options.B: No simple objects exist; only composite wholes are real. Apparent simples like atoms are 'abstractions from unified fields' causing particle-like experiences.
options.C: No spatial relations exist; only temporally extended processes are real. Apparent objects are 'standing waves in causal flux' creating stable experiences.
options.D: No composite objects exist; only mereological simples are real. Apparent composites like tables are 'simples arranged table-wise' causing table-like experiences.

questions.question_text: David Lewis's counterpart theory provides an alternative semantics for modal claims. How does it analyze 'I might have been a banker,' and what relation replaces identity?

options.A: An abstract property-set including 'banker' is consistent with my essential nature. Conceptual entailment, not resemblance, connects individuals to possible roles.
options.B: A counterpart resembling me in another possible world is a banker -- I do not exist there myself. Resemblance, not identity, links counterparts across worlds.
options.C: My identical self in another possible world chose banking instead of philosophy. Strict numerical identity, not resemblance, links individuals across all worlds.
options.D: A temporal stage of me at a different time became a banker in actuality. Causal continuity, not resemblance, links successive person-stages together.

questions.question_text: Causal set theory proposes a fundamentally discrete structure for spacetime as an approach to quantum gravity. What mathematical structure models spacetime, and what is Sorkin's slogan?

options.A: Spacetime is modeled as a continuous differentiable manifold of point-events related by metric distance. Sorkin's slogan: 'Curvature + Matter = Gravity.'
options.B: Spacetime is modeled as a lattice of spin networks connected by holonomy transformations along edges. Sorkin's slogan: 'Loops + Nodes = Spacetime.'
options.C: Spacetime is modeled as a simplicial complex of triangulated surfaces related by conformal symmetry. Sorkin's slogan: 'Triangles + Topology = Dynamics.'
options.D: Spacetime is modeled as a locally finite partially ordered set of discrete events related by causal order. Sorkin's slogan: 'Order + Number = Geometry.'

questions.question_text: Jonathan Schaffer defends priority monism, a distinctive form of monism in contemporary metaphysics. What is the one fundamental entity, and what physical phenomenon motivates the view?

options.A: The fundamental physical field is the one fundamental entity; particles are derivative excitations. The Higgs mechanism motivates the view, suggesting unified mass generation.
options.B: The cosmos is the one fundamental entity; all proper parts are metaphysically derivative. Quantum entanglement motivates the view, suggesting the universe is one entangled system.
options.C: Spacetime is the one fundamental entity; matter and energy are derivative modifications of geometry. Dark energy motivates the view, suggesting accelerating cosmic expansion.
options.D: A single universal substance is the one fundamental entity; distinct objects are mere appearances. Conservation of mass-energy motivates the view, suggesting underlying unity.
